Award.AwardTitle: Redox Properties of Reduced Semiconductor Nanocrystals
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry Program supports the efforts of Professor Daniel Gamelin of the University of Washington to study the redox properties of reduced semiconductor nanocrystals. The interconversion of chemical, electrical, and optical energies is critical to many advanced technologies. Nanoscale semiconductors play central roles in many of these technologies. This research is addressing fundamental aspects of the redox and photoredox properties of colloidal semiconductor nanocrystals, focusing on interconversion of the various forms of energy and yielding new materials and new fundamental knowledge relevant to a wide variety of catalytic, opto-electronic, and energy-conversion technologies. Characterization of reduced-nanocrystal physical properties, electronic structures, and redox properties is building important bridges connecting fields of semiconductor nanoscience, photochemistry, electrochemistry, spectroscopy, and energy and information sciences. This project is also providing participants with advanced interdisciplinary education and training, and preparing them for careers in science, engineering, and education. Integration of research and education is being emphasized through involvement of undergraduate students in the research, incorporation of experiments and research concepts from this project into the University of Washington undergraduate curriculum, close collaboration with faculty from undergraduate institutions, and outreach activities at regional community colleges, high schools, and community events.

This project aims to explore the redox properties of colloidal semiconductor nanocrystals including ZnO, In2O3, CdSe, CdS, CdTe and PbS, and related compositions, focusing on the development and understanding of solution-phase reduced nanocrystals containing excess delocalized conduction-band electrons. A combination of advanced syntheses, sophisticated spectroscopies, and analytical methods is being applied to develop reduced colloidal semiconductor nanocrystals and to understand their electronic structures and redox characteristics. This research emphasizes the development of new materials, new quantitative methodologies, and new redox chemistries. The integration of synthesis, spectroscopy, reactivity studies, electronic-structure studies, and quantitative analysis is facilitating the discovery and development of advanced materials, and elucidating fundamental structure/function relationships in these unusual materials. This project is providing advanced interdisciplinary education and training for participants in the areas of inorganic, physical, and materials chemistries, preparing them for careers in science, engineering, technology innovation, and education. These activities have a broader impact through integration of research and education, particularly at the undergraduate level, and through outreach activities involving regional community colleges, high schools, and the general community.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project broadened the scope of redox-active nanocrystals (NCs) from oxides to chalcogenides, and introduced new quantitative methodologies for probing NC redox properties. A key outcome was development of new methodologies for measuring the redox potentials of free-standing colloidal semiconductor nanocrystals, first achieved using an optical redox indicator approach. We then introduced a new spectroelectrochemical potentiometry method for measuring the redox potentials of colloidal semiconductor NCs. Among other insights, this method showed that Fermi levels (EF) of solutions of NCs possessing an average of just one conduction-band (CB) electron per NC can vary by over 600 meV, depending upon the method of charge compensation, and showed that NC redox potentials are very strongly affected by surface stoichiometry. We also applied spectroelectrochemical potentiometry to quantify fundamental differences between excess valence-band (VB) holes in colloidal copper-sulfide NCs formed using I2 or Fc+. Their differences reflect the different modes of charge-carrier compensation, with surface-compensated VB holes being hundreds of mV less stable than cation-vacancy-compensated holes at the same carrier density.

            Potentiometric titration was used to measure EF in colloidal n-type ZnO NCs under equilibrium conditions across a range of carrier densities and NC volumes. Different titrants were used to lower or raise EF by selectively removing CB electrons or charge-balancing H+, and a linear relationship was found between EF and <n>, which was used to quantify the capacitance. Surprisingly, the results were described well using a classical, double-layer capacitance model. We then developed a quantum/classical model for describing EF and wavefunction probability densities in multiply charged NCs. This "Charged Sphere" model successfully accounted for interelectronic and electron-cation interactions. Potentiometric titration revealed extremely large capacitances in free-standing colloidal Zn0.99Fe0.01O NCs, attributable to the presence of mid-gap Fe(3d) orbitals that can reversibly capture and store added electrons, identifying these materials as attractive “soluble supercapacitors” for solution-phase charge-storage technologies.

            A great deal was learned about the redox chemistry of CdSe NCs. We showed that photodoping is initiated by dark thermal surface pre-reduction and then proceeds via photooxidation of these reduced surfaces. We identified that the Cd2+/Sex− ratios at CdSe NC surfaces not only impact band-edge potentials but also dramatically and alter the slow (ms to hr) spontaneous surface electron trapping. The results suggested that this very slow CB-electron trapping comes from stochastic appearance of new mid-gap surface traps, similar to previous proposals explaining distributed blinking dynamics. We also incorporated excess CB electrons into colloidal CdSe/CdS core/shell QDs with various shell thicknesses and showed that the electrons become increasingly stable with increasing shell thickness. In QDs containing two extra CB electrons, we observed separate photoluminescence from recombination of discretized S- and P-type electrons, as well as corresponding dynamic signatures of four-carrier negative tetrons.

            Finally, we developed a successful route to photodoping colloidal PbSe QDs involving UV photolysis of THF to generate radicals that transfer electrons to the QDs. This unique procedure allows precise control over QD carrier densities. At maximum photodoping, we observed complete filling of the S-type CB orbital as well as partial population of the higher P-type orbitals. The high-quality absorption spectra permitted unambiguous assignment of the long-debated second excitonic absorption maximum.

            Overall, we achieved the major objectives of the project, including (i) development of a general methodology for measuring EF of colloidal NCs; (ii) extension of photodoping, redox, and electrochemical methods from oxides to chalcogenides; (iii) mechanistic investigation of photodoping chemistries; and (iv) clarification of surface-dipole and counter ion effects in colloidal NC redox properties.

            Each undergraduate student, graduate student, and postdoc involved in this research participated in multiple aspects of the research described above. They received advanced training in the complementary areas of inorganic chemistry, physical chemistry, surface science, theory, materials science, and nanotechnology. This very broad experience prepared these participants well for future challenges in academia and industry. Senior graduate students and postdocs were also each involved in the mentoring of at least one other graduate or undergraduate student, in leadership of joint group meetings, and in responsibility for major instrumentation. In the course of this project, the PI has worked to integrate research findings from this project into his teaching and outreach activities, and to engage the broader community in related energy and materials science education. Project participanjts have been active in outreach through UW's (state-funded) Clean Energy Institute and UW's NSF Molecular Engineering Materials Center. Participants also helped to staff a hands-on science display booth at community events held in conjunction with Seattle's Pacific Science Center. These activities engage regional high-school students and members of the broader public in discussions about energy and science, stimulating them to consider new ideas for solving current or future technological challenges.


Last Modified: 03/10/2020
Modified by: Daniel R Gamelin
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: This project broadened the scope of redox-active nanocrystals (NCs) from oxides to chalcogenides, and introduced new quantitative methodologies for probing NC redox properties. A key outcome was development of new methodologies for measuring the redox potentials of free-standing colloidal semiconductor nanocrystals, first achieved using an optical redox indicator approach. We then introduced a new spectroelectrochemical potentiometry method for measuring the redox potentials of colloidal semiconductor NCs. Among other insights, this method showed that Fermi levels (EF) of solutions of NCs possessing an average of just one conduction-band (CB) electron per NC can vary by over 600 meV, depending upon the method of charge compensation, and showed that NC redox potentials are very strongly affected by surface stoichiometry. We also applied spectroelectrochemical potentiometry to quantify fundamental differences between excess valence-band (VB) holes in colloidal copper-sulfide NCs formed using I2 or Fc+. Their differences reflect the different modes of charge-carrier compensation, with surface-compensated VB holes being hundreds of mV less stable than cation-vacancy-compensated holes at the same carrier density. Potentiometric titration was used to measure EF in colloidal n-type ZnO NCs under equilibrium conditions across a range of carrier densities and NC volumes. Different titrants were used to lower or raise EF by selectively removing CB electrons or charge-balancing H+, and a linear relationship was found between EF and <n>, which was used to quantify the capacitance. Surprisingly, the results were described well using a classical, double-layer capacitance model. We then developed a quantum/classical model for describing EF and wavefunction probability densities in multiply charged NCs. This "Charged Sphere" model successfully accounted for interelectronic and electron-cation interactions. Potentiometric titration revealed extremely large capacitances in free-standing colloidal Zn0.99Fe0.01O NCs, attributable to the presence of mid-gap Fe(3d) orbitals that can reversibly capture and store added electrons, identifying these materials as attractive "soluble supercapacitors" for solution-phase charge-storage technologies. A great deal was learned about the redox chemistry of CdSe NCs. We showed that photodoping is initiated by dark thermal surface pre-reduction and then proceeds via photooxidation of these reduced surfaces. We identified that the Cd2+/Sex− ratios at CdSe NC surfaces not only impact band-edge potentials but also dramatically and alter the slow (ms to hr) spontaneous surface electron trapping. We also incorporated excess CB electrons into colloidal CdSe/CdS core/shell QDs with various shell thicknesses and showed that the electrons become increasingly stable with increasing shell thickness. In QDs containing two extra CB electrons, we observed separate photoluminescence from recombination of discretized S- and P-type electrons, as well as corresponding dynamic signatures of four-carrier negative tetrons. Finally, we developed a successful route to photodoping colloidal PbSe QDs involving UV photolysis of THF to generate radicals that transfer electrons to the QDs. This unique procedure allows precise control over QD carrier densities. At maximum photodoping, we observed complete filling of the S-type CB orbital as well as partial population of the higher P-type orbitals. The high-quality absorption spectra permitted unambiguous assignment of the long-debated second excitonic absorption maximum. Overall, we achieved the major objectives of the project, including (i) development of a general methodology for measuring EF of colloidal NCs; (ii) extension of photodoping, redox, and electrochemical methods from oxides to chalcogenides; (iii) mechanistic investigation of photodoping chemistries; and (iv) clarification of surface-dipole and counter ion effects in colloidal NC redox properties. Each undergraduate student, graduate student, and postdoc involved in this research participated in multiple aspects of the research described above. They received advanced training in the complementary areas of inorganic chemistry, physical chemistry, surface science, theory, materials science, and nanotechnology. This very broad experience prepared these participants well for future challenges in academia and industry. Senior graduate students and postdocs were also each involved in the mentoring of at least one other graduate or undergraduate student, in leadership of joint group meetings, and in responsibility for major instrumentation. In the course of this project, the PI has worked to integrate research findings from this project into his teaching and outreach activities, and to engage the broader community in related energy and materials science education. Project participanjts have been active in outreach through UW's (state-funded) Clean Energy Institute and UW's NSF Molecular Engineering Materials Center. Participants also helped to staff a hands-on science display booth at community events held in conjunction with Seattle's Pacific Science Center. These activities engage regional high-school students and members of the broader public in discussions about energy and science, stimulating them to consider new ideas for solving current or future technological challenges.
